title: Static template catalog for demo (Railway-style one-click deploys)
description:
## Context

For the demo and production use, we need two distinct addon-related surfaces:

1. **User flow** ‚Äî project members deploy addon instances (postgres, redis, etc.) into their projects from a Railway-style catalog picker.
2. **Admin flow** ‚Äî platform admins manage the addon catalog (create definitions, update chart versions, deactivate entries, add cluster-scoped overrides).

The catalog is seeded with 6 global definitions (postgres, redis, mongodb, kafka, mysql, rabbitmq) but admins need a UI to manage them over time.

---

## User flow: Deploy an addon instance

### Page: /projects/[id]/addons (list + launch)

- Shows all running addon instances for the project
- "Add Addon" button opens the catalog picker

### Catalog picker (modal or /projects/[id]/addons/new)

- Fetches GET /v1/addon-definitions (pass ?cluster_id= for cluster-specific overrides)
- Displays cards: icon + name + description + tags
- User clicks a card, enters an instance name, optionally overrides values
- Submits POST /v1/addon-instances { project_id, name, definition_id }
- Redirects to addon instance detail, phase starts as Pending

### Custom deploy (advanced)

- "Custom" option in picker: user supplies type + chart { repo, name, version } + values
- Submits POST /v1/addon-instances { project_id, name, type, chart, values } (no definition_id)

### Addon instance detail: /projects/[id]/addons/[instance_id]

- Shows phase badge (Pending / Deploying / Running / Degraded / Failed)
- Shows exports (connection strings) once Running
- Delete button ‚Üí DELETE /v1/addon-instances/{id}

---

## Admin flow: Manage addon catalog

### Page: /admin/addon-definitions (list)

- Fetches GET /v1/addon-definitions?is_active=true (and optionally false to show inactive)
- Table: name, slug, type, chart version, cluster scope, active toggle
- "New Definition" button
- Row actions: Edit, Deactivate

### Page: /admin/addon-definitions/new

- Form: name, slug, type, icon, description, tags, cluster_id (optional), chart config (repo/name/version), default_values (YAML/JSON editor)
- Submits POST /v1/addon-definitions

### Page: /admin/addon-definitions/[id]/edit

- Pre-filled form from GET /v1/addon-definitions/{id}
- Submits PATCH /v1/addon-definitions/{id}
- Supports updating chart version (common operation when chart releases new version)

### Deactivate

- Toggle or button ‚Üí DELETE /v1/addon-definitions/{id} (soft-delete, sets is_active=false)
- Existing instances are unaffected (definition_id FK is nullable, SET NULL on delete)

---

## API reference

### Catalog (admin-managed)
```
GET    /v1/addon-definitions              ?cluster_id=&type=&is_active=true
POST   /v1/addon-definitions              { cluster_id?, name, slug, type, icon, tags, chart_config, default_values }
GET    /v1/addon-definitions/{id}
PATCH  /v1/addon-definitions/{id}         partial update
DELETE /v1/addon-definitions/{id}         soft-delete (is_active=false)
```

### Instances (user-facing)
```
POST   /v1/addon-instances               { project_id, name, definition_id } or { project_id, name, type, chart, values }
GET    /v1/addon-instances?project_id=X  list for a project
GET    /v1/addon-instances/{id}
DELETE /v1/addon-instances/{id}
```

### AddonDefinitionRead shape
```json
{
  "id": "uuid",
  "cluster_id": null,
  "name": "PostgreSQL",
  "slug": "postgres",
  "description": "Open-source relational database",
  "icon": "üêò",
  "tags": ["database", "popular"],
  "type": "postgres",
  "chart_config": { "repo": "...", "name": "postgresql", "version": "12.1.2" },
  "default_values": null,
  "is_active": true
}
```

### AddonInstanceRead shape
```json
{
  "id": "uuid",
  "definition_id": "uuid or null",
  "project_id": "uuid",
  "name": "postgres-main",
  "type": "postgres",
  "chart_config": { ... },
  "phase": "Running",
  "exports": { "host": "postgres.svc", "port": "5432" },
  "deployed_at": "2026-02-19T..."
}
```

---

## Notes

- The 6 global seed definitions cover the common cases ‚Äî admins only need the UI for adding new types or updating chart versions.
- Cluster-scoped definitions (cluster_id set) allow per-cluster overrides, e.g. HA Postgres only for production clusters. The admin form should support selecting a cluster.
- Chart refs in seed data use Bitnami placeholders ‚Äî see kubenest-backend-a0z for the migration to official charts.
- Phase updates arrive via SSE (kubenest-ui-9ch) ‚Äî the instance detail page should subscribe to addon_status_update events.
notes:
## Backend API ‚Äî UPDATED (addon definition/instance split, 2026-02-19)

The addon backend was refactored into a two-layer architecture. All frontend addon code must use the new endpoints.

### Catalog API ‚Äî /v1/addon-definitions
```
GET  /v1/addon-definitions                     ‚Üí AddonDefinitionList
     ?cluster_id=&type=&is_active=true
GET  /v1/addon-definitions/{id}                ‚Üí AddonDefinitionRead
POST /v1/addon-definitions                     ‚Üí create (admin only)
PATCH /v1/addon-definitions/{id}               ‚Üí update
DELETE /v1/addon-definitions/{id}              ‚Üí soft-delete (is_active=false)
```

AddonDefinitionRead shape:
```json
{
  "id": "uuid",
  "cluster_id": null,
  "name": "PostgreSQL",
  "slug": "postgres",
  "description": "Open-source relational database",
  "icon": "üêò",
  "tags": ["database", "popular"],
  "type": "postgres",
  "chart_config": { "repo": "...", "name": "postgresql", "version": "12.1.2" },
  "default_values": null,
  "is_active": true
}
```

Global definitions (cluster_id=null) are always returned. Pass ?cluster_id=X to also get cluster-specific overrides.
6 standard addons are seeded: postgres, redis, mongodb, kafka, mysql, rabbitmq.

### Instance API ‚Äî /v1/addon-instances
```
POST   /v1/addon-instances                     ‚Üí deploy ‚Üí 201
GET    /v1/addon-instances?project_id=X        ‚Üí list (project_id required)
GET    /v1/addon-instances/{id}                ‚Üí detail
DELETE /v1/addon-instances/{id}                ‚Üí uninstall ‚Üí 204
```

AddonInstanceCreate (from catalog definition):
```json
{
  "project_id": "uuid",
  "name": "postgres-main",
  "definition_id": "uuid"
}
```

AddonInstanceCreate (custom, no definition):
```json
{
  "project_id": "uuid",
  "name": "my-redis",
  "type": "redis",
  "chart": { "repo": "...", "name": "redis", "version": "17.0.0" },
  "values": {}
}
```

AddonInstanceRead shape (same phase/exports fields as before):
```json
{
  "id": "uuid",
  "definition_id": "uuid or null",
  "project_id": "uuid",
  "name": "postgres-main",
  "type": "postgres",
  "chart_config": { ... },
  "phase": "Pending",
  "exports": null,
  "deployed_at": null
}
```

### What changes in the frontend

1. Template catalog page: can now be API-driven ‚Äî fetch GET /v1/addon-definitions instead of using a static TEMPLATES constant. Still fine to keep TEMPLATES as a fallback/loading state.

2. Deploy flow from catalog: pass definition_id in the AddonInstanceCreate body (no need to supply chart manually ‚Äî backend copies it from the definition).

3. Addon list page: change GET /v1/addons?project_id=X ‚Üí GET /v1/addon-instances?project_id=X

4. Addon deploy: change POST /v1/addons ‚Üí POST /v1/addon-instances

5. Addon delete: change DELETE /v1/addons/{id} ‚Üí DELETE /v1/addon-instances/{id}

6. URL route rename: /projects/[id]/addons ‚Üí /projects/[id]/addon-instances (or keep UI path the same, just fix the API calls)

### Old API (deleted ‚Äî do not use)
- POST /v1/addons
- GET /v1/addons
- GET /v1/addons/{id}
- DELETE /v1/addons/{id}

### op3 intent handler ‚úÖ
addon_install and addon_uninstall are handled ‚Äî same as before, no change from frontend perspective.

### Chart refs
Bitnami charts are placeholders in seed data. See kubenest-backend-a0z for replacement task. Deploy flow is fully wired.

title: Add Helm chart deploy mode to workload creation form
description: ## Context The backend now supports deploying workloads via custom Helm charts instead of the default kubenest-workload chart. The API accepts two new optional fields on POST /workloads: - `chart`: `{ repo: string, name: string, version: string }` - `values`: arbitrary JSON object of Helm values The workload response object now includes `chart_config: { chart?: ChartSpec, values?: Record } | null`. ## Goal Extend the "Deploy New Workload" form and workload detail page to support Helm chart deployments alongside the existing image-based flow. --- ## Files to change ### 1. `types/api.ts` Add `ChartSpec` interface and extend existing types: \`\`\`ts export interface ChartSpec { repo: string; // Helm repo URL, e.g. https://charts.bitnami.com/bitnami name: string; // Chart name, e.g. postgresql version: string; // Semver chart version, e.g. 12.1.2 } \`\`\` Add to `Workload` interface: \`\`\`ts chart_config: { chart?: ChartSpec; values?: Record } | null; \`\`\` Add to `CreateWorkloadRequest`: \`\`\`ts chart?: ChartSpec; values?: Record; \`\`\` --- ### 2. `app/projects/[id]/workloads/new/page.tsx` #### Deploy mode toggle Add a mode selector at the top of the form with two options: **Image** (default) and **Helm Chart**. Use `useState<'image' | 'chart'>('image')`. #### Updated Zod schema Remove the hard `z.string().min(1)` requirement on `image`. Add chart fields. Use `.superRefine()` to cross-validate: - In `image` mode: `image` is required - In `chart` mode: `chart.repo`, `chart.name`, `chart.version` are all required; `image` is ignored \`\`\`ts const chartSpecSchema = z.object({ repo: z.string().url('Must be a valid URL'), name: z.string().min(1, 'Chart name is required'), version: z.string().min(1, 'Version is required'), }); const workloadSchema = z.object({ name: z.string().min(1).regex(/^[a-z0-9-]+$/), image: z.string().optional(), replicas: z.number().int().min(0).max(100), port: z.number().int().min(1).max(65535).optional().nullable(), ingress: ingressSchema.optional(), chart: chartSpecSchema.optional(), valuesYaml: z.string().optional(), // raw YAML/JSON text input, parsed before submit }); \`\`\` #### Conditional field rendering When mode is `'image'`: show `Container Image` field (required), hide chart fields. When mode is `'chart'`: hide image field, show three chart fields (Repo, Name, Version) + optional Helm Values textarea. #### Helm Values textarea - Collapsible section (same pattern as Ingress) - Accepts YAML or JSON (use `js-yaml` if already in deps, else JSON only is fine) - Parse to object before submitting; show parse error inline if invalid #### `onSubmit` handler changes \`\`\`ts // image mode (current behavior unchanged) if (mode === 'image') { payload.image = data.image; } // chart mode if (mode === 'chart') { payload.chart = data.chart; if (data.valuesYaml) { try { payload.values = JSON.parse(data.valuesYaml); // or yaml.load() } catch { setError('valuesYaml', { message: 'Invalid JSON/YAML' }); return; } } } \`\`\` --- ### 3. `app/workloads/[id]/page.tsx` In the **Workload Details** card, update the source row: - If `workload.chart_config?.chart` exists: show chart badge with repo/name@version instead of the Image row - If `workload.image` exists: show the existing Image row (no change) - Both can coexist (image + values override case), but chart takes priority as the label Replace the hardcoded `Image` entry in the details array with: \`\`\`tsx workload.chart_config?.chart ? { label: 'Helm Chart', value: ( {workload.chart_config.chart.name}@{workload.chart_config.chart.version} ({workload.chart_config.chart.repo}) ), } : { label: 'Image', value: ( {workload.image} ), }, \`\`\` If `chart_config.values` is non-empty, add a collapsible **Helm Values** section below the details card showing the values as formatted JSON. --- ## Acceptance criteria - [ ] Deploy form shows Image/Helm Chart toggle - [ ] Image mode: existing behaviour unchanged, all existing tests pass - [ ] Chart mode: chart repo/name/version fields shown and validated - [ ] Chart mode: Helm Values textarea accepts JSON and shows parse errors - [ ] Submitting in chart mode sends `{ chart: {...}, values: {...} }` in the API payload (no `image`) - [ ] Workload detail page shows "Helm Chart" source row instead of "Image" when `chart_config` is set - [ ] TypeScript types are updated ‚Äî no `any` casts needed ## Notes - `WorkloadPhase` in `types/api.ts` currently has lowercase values (`running`, `failed`, etc.) but the backend returns Title-case (`Running`, `Failed`). Check if this mismatch causes any issues while you are in this file. - No new dependencies are strictly required; use JSON.parse for values unless js-yaml is already installed. - The `lib/api/workloads.ts` and `hooks/useWorkloads.ts` files do NOT need changes ‚Äî they pass the payload through as-is.
close_reason: Implemented: Image/Helm Chart toggle on workload form, ChartSpec types, chart_config on workload detail page with collapsible Helm Values section. All typechecks pass.

title: Workload metrics: real-time CPU/memory/request charts in workload detail
description:
## Context

When kube-prometheus-stack is installed as a cluster addon (optional), Prometheus scrapes workload metrics and Grafana provides dashboards. The workload detail page should surface basic metrics inline without requiring users to open Grafana directly.

## What to display

Basic real-time metrics for the workload (last 30 minutes, auto-refresh every 15s):
- CPU usage (millicores)
- Memory usage (MiB)
- HTTP request rate (req/s) ‚Äî only if the workload exposes metrics endpoint
- Error rate ‚Äî optional

These are fetched directly from the Prometheus API (not Grafana embed) so we control the rendering.

## How it works

Cluster model (backend) will have a prometheus_url field when monitoring is installed.
The backend exposes a proxy/passthrough endpoint:
  GET /workloads/:id/metrics?query=<promql>&start=&end=&step=

(Proxying avoids CORS issues and keeps Prometheus internal to the cluster.)

Alternatively, if Grafana is exposed, embed a pre-built dashboard panel via iframe.

## UI changes (app/workloads/[id]/page.tsx)

Add a **Metrics** card below the Scale Controls card. Shown only when:
- `workload.phase === 'Running'` (or 'Degraded')
- `cluster.prometheus_url` is set (need to fetch cluster via project)

Inside the card:
- Three small sparkline charts (Recharts or similar, already check if in deps)
- Time range selector: 15m | 1h | 6h
- Auto-refresh toggle (on by default, 15s interval using useInterval)
- Loading skeleton while fetching

## API client changes (lib/api/)

New file: `lib/api/metrics.ts`
```ts
export const metricsApi = {
  query: (workloadId: string, params: MetricsQueryParams) =>
    apiClient.get<MetricsResponse>(`/workloads/${workloadId}/metrics`, { params }),
};
```

## Hook (hooks/useWorkloadMetrics.ts)

```ts
export function useWorkloadMetrics(workloadId: string, range: '15m' | '1h' | '6h') {
  return useQuery({
    queryKey: ['metrics', workloadId, range],
    queryFn: () => metricsApi.query(workloadId, { range }),
    refetchInterval: 15_000,
    enabled: !!workloadId,
  });
}
```

## Backend prerequisite

A GET /workloads/:id/metrics endpoint that queries Prometheus and returns:
```json
{
  "cpu": [{ "t": 1234567890, "v": 125.4 }, ...],
  "memory": [{ "t": 1234567890, "v": 256.0 }, ...],
  "rps": [{ "t": 1234567890, "v": 12.3 }, ...]
}
```
This backend endpoint is a separate bead. The frontend can stub it initially with mock data.

## Notes

- Check if Recharts or similar is already in package.json before adding a dependency.
- Metrics card should gracefully degrade: if cluster has no prometheus_url, show a subtle
  "Install the monitoring addon to view metrics" message instead of the charts.
- Do NOT embed Grafana iframes ‚Äî too heavy, auth is complex, poor UX.
- The monitoring addon (kube-prometheus-stack) is optional at the cluster level.
  Backend bead: "Add prometheus_url to Cluster and expose /workloads/:id/metrics proxy"
